Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story: Every Sunday morning, I wake up to the sound of my parents moving around the kitchen. As their daughter, I know how much they rely on me, especially since Dad’s health started to decline. I make it a point to check in, asking if everything is going well at home, listening to their worries, and offering comfort. Lately, though, I’ve felt a growing pull to attend Sunday worship at church. My faith is important to me, and I want to be part of the community, to worship and grow spiritually. But the church service overlaps with the time my parents seem to need me most. I can see the relief in their eyes when I’m there, and the disappointment when I mention church. I feel torn—my heart aches with guilt at the thought of leaving them alone, even for a few hours, but I also long for the peace and connection I find at church. The expectations from both sides weigh heavily on me, and I find myself wrestling with what it means to be a good daughter and a faithful Christian, unsure which path to choose.
